Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product. Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated.

Label: Pool Identifier
Notes: Identifier used for pooling subjects to assign a single finding to multiple subjects. If POOLID is entered, POOLDEF records must exist for each subject and the USUBJID must be null. Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated.

Label: Focus of Study-Specific Interest
Notes: Identification of a focus of study-specific interest on or within a subject or specimen as defined in the protocol for which a measurement, test, or examination was performed, such as a drug application site, e.g., "Injection site 1," "Biopsy site 1," "Treated site 1." the value in this variable should have inherent semantic value.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: The sequence number must be unique for each record within a USUBJID or POOLID, whichever applies for the record.

Label: Name of Actual Treatment
Notes: Name of the treatment, as defined by the protocol.

Label: Dose per Administration
Notes: Amount of treatment administered.

Label: Dose Description
Notes: If the amount of treatment administered cannot be represented as a number and populated in EXDOSE, this field is used to describe the amount of treatment administered. Example: 200-400.

Label: Dose Units
Notes: Units for EXDOSE or EXDOSTXT. Examples: ng, mg, or mg/kg.

Label: Dose Form
Notes: Dose form for treatment (form administered). Examples: TABLET, LOTION.

Label: Dosing Frequency Per Interval
Notes: Usually expressed as the number of repeated administrations of EXDOSE within a specific time period. Examples: QD (once daily), BID (2x daily).

Label: Route of Administration
Notes: Route of administration for EXTRT. Examples: ORAL GAVAGE, DERMAL, INTRAVENOUS.

Label: Lot Number
Notes: Lot Number(s) or Batch Number(s) of the EXTRT test article. If mixed lots of the test article are administered during the same constant dosing interval, this should be represented as "Lot A;Lot B." Mixed lots are produced by the mixing of Lots a and B of the test article into one solution, suspension, or dietary food concentration. If no test article was administered, EXLOT should be null.

Label: Location of Dose Administration
Notes: Specifies anatomical location (site) of administration. Example: LEFT HINDLIMB for a topical application or an injection site number. Each administration will require its own record.

Label: Method of Administration
Notes: Method of the dose administration. Example: INFUSION.

Label: Treatment Vehicle
Notes: Describes vehicle used for treatment. Example: SALINE.

Label: Amount Administered
Notes: The amount (volume or weight) of the treatment compound plus vehicle administered in a single dose. This is not to be confused with EXDOSE. EXDOSE refers to the amount of test material administered to the subject.

Label: Amount Administered Units
Notes: Units for EXVAMT (per dose administration).

Label: Reason for Dose Adjustment
Notes: Describes reason or explanation of why a dose is adjusted - used only when an adjustment is represented in EX. May be used for variations from protocol-specified doses or changes from expected doses (e.g., when dose is adjusted due to toxicity).

Label: Start Date/Time of Treatment
Notes: Date/Time when administration of the treatment indicated by EXTRT and EXDOSE began, in ISO 8601 format.

Label: End Date/Time of Treatment
Notes: Date/Time when administration of the treatment indicated by EXTRT and EXDOSE ended, in ISO 8601 format.

Label: Study Day of Start of Treatment
Notes: Study day when administration of the treatment began, in integer days. The algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in the Demographics (DM) domain.

Label: Study Day of End of Treatment
Notes: Study day when administration of the treatment ended, in integer days. The algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in the Demographics (DM) domain.

Label: Duration of Treatment
Notes: Duration and unit of time for a continuous treatment. This may be used to denote the length of an infusion (e.g., PT10M to indicate 10 minutes).

Label: Planned Time Point Name
Notes: Text description of time when a dose should be given. Note: This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point, such as time of last dose. See EXTPTNUM and EXTPTREF.

Label: Planned Time Point Number
Notes: Numerical version of EXTPT to aid in sorting.

Label: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref
Notes: Planned elapsed time (in ISO 8601 format) relative to the planned fixed reference (EXTPTREF). This variable is useful where there are repetitive measures. Not a clock time or a date time variable. Represented as an ISO 8601 duration. Examples: "- PT15M" to represent the period of 15 minutes prior to the reference point indicated by EXTPTREF, or "PT8H" to represent the period of 8 hours after the reference point indicated by EXTPTREF.

Label: Time Point Reference
Notes: Name of the fixed reference point referred to by EXELTM, if used for EXTPTNUM, and EXTPT. It is recommended that EXTPTREF be as descriptive as possible so the reference time point can be inferred without looking at other variables. Examples: Previous dose, previous feed.

Label: Date/Time of Reference Time Point
Notes: Date/Time of the reference time point, EXTPTREF.

Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all application or submissions involving the product.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain. May be any valid number.

Label: Group Identifier
Notes: Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject and can be used to support relationships within the domain and between domains using RELREC. This is not the treatment group number.

Label: Sponsor-Defined Identifier
Notes: Sponsor-defined reference identifier.

Label: Test Short Name
Notes: Short name of the measurement, test, or examination described in RETEST. It can be used as a column name when converting a dataset from a vertical to a horizontal format. The value in RETESTCD cannot be longer than 8 characters, nor can it start with a number (e.g., "1TEST" is not valid). RETESTCD cannot contain characters other than letters, numbers, or underscores. Examples: RESPRATE, TIDALVOL, MV.

Label: Test Name
Notes: Long name for RETESTCD. The value in RETEST cannot be longer than 40 characters. Examples: Respiratory Rate, Tidal Volume, Minute Volume.

Label: Position of Subject During Test
Notes: Position of the subject during the measurement or examination, If the subject is restrained, populate with the position (example SITTING or STANDING); otherwise, populate with UNCONSTRAINED.

Label: Result or Findings as Collected
Notes: Result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.

Label: Unit of the Original Result
Notes: The unit for the original result. The unit of the original result should be mapped to a synonymous unit on the Controlled Terminology (http://www.cdisc.org/terminology) list.

Label: Standardized Result in Character Format
Notes: Contains the result value for all findings, copied or derived from REORRES in a standard format or standard units. RESTRESC should store all results or findings in character format; if results are numeric, they should also be stored in numeric format in RESTRESN.

Label: Standardized Result in Numeric Format
Notes: Used for continuous or numeric results or findings in standard format; contains the numeric form of RESTRESC. RESTRESN should store all numeric test results or findings.

Label: Unit of the Standardized Result
Notes: Standardized unit used for RESTRESC and RESTRESN.

Label: Completion Status
Notes: Used to indicate when a test is not done or result is missing. Should be null if a result exists in REORRES.

Label: Reason Not Done
Notes: Describes why RESTAT is NOT DONE, such as BROKEN EQUIPMENT.

Label: Method of Test
Notes: Method of the test or examination. Examples: Whole body plethysmograph, Head-out plethysmograph, Invasive.

Label: Consciousness State
Notes: Consciousness state of the subject at the time of measurement. Examples: CONSCIOUS, SEMI-CONSCIOUS, UNCONSCIOUS

Label: Baseline Flag
Notes: A baseline indicator may be used to calculate differences or changes from baseline. Value should be Y or null. The baseline flag is sponsor defined.

Label: Derived Flag
Notes: Used to indicate a derived record. The value should be Y or null.

Label: Exclusion Flag
Notes: Y if the result should be excluded from all calculations, otherwise null.

Label: Reason for Exclusion
Notes: The reason the result should be excluded from all calculations. Used only when REEXCLFL is Y.

Label: Unscheduled Flag
Notes: Indicates whether the timing of the performed test or observation was unscheduled. If a test or observation was performed based upon a schedule defined in the protocol, this flag should be null. Expected values are Y or null.

Label: Date/Time of Respiratory Measurement
Notes: Date/Time of respiratory data collection, in ISO 8601 format. For measurements related to a continuous evaluation interval, REDTC should be used to indicate the start date/time of that interval.

Label: End Date/Time of Respiratory Measurement
Notes: Date/Time of end of the respiratory evaluation interval, in ISO 8601 format. Should be populated when REDTC represents the start date/time of a continuous evaluation interval.

Label: Study Day of Respiratory Measurement
Notes: Study day of respiratory data collection, in integer days. For measurements related to a continuous evaluation interval, REDY can be used to indicate start day of that interval. The algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in the Demographics (DM) domain.

Label: End Study Day of Respiratory Measurement
Notes: Study day of the respiratory data collection, in integer days. Can be populated when REDY represents the start day of a continuous evaluation interval. The algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in the Demographics (DM) domain.

Label: Nominal Study Day for Tabulations
Notes: Nominal study day used for grouping records for observations that may occur on different days into a single reported study day. Should be an integer.

Label: Label for Nominal Study Day
Notes: A label for a given value of RENOMDY as presented in the study report. Examples: Pretreatment, Week 4, Day 28.

Label: Planned Time Point Name
Notes: Text description of time when respiratory data should be collected. This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point, such as time of last dose. See RETPTNUM and RETPTREF. Examples: Predose, 1 Hour Postdose.

Label: Planned Time Point Number
Notes: Numerical version of RETPT to aid in sorting.

Label: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref
Notes: Planned elapsed time (in ISO 8601 format) relative to a fixed time point reference (RETPTREF). This variable is useful where there are repetitive measures. Not a clock time or a date time variable. Represented as an ISO 8601 duration. Examples: "-PT15M" to represent the period of 15 minutes prior to the reference point indicated by RETPTREF, or "PT8H" to represent the period of 8 hours after the reference point indicated by RETPTREF.

Label: Time Point Reference
Notes: Name of the fixed reference point referred to by REELTM, if used for RETPTNUM, and RETPT. It is recommended that RETPTREF be as descriptive as possible so the reference time point can be inferred without looking at others variables. Example: DAY 1 FIRST DOSE.

Label: Date/Time of Reference Time Point
Notes: Date/Time of the reference time point, RETPTREF.

Label: Evaluation Interval
Notes: Length of evaluation interval in ISO 8601 duration format. Used in place of RESTINT and REENINT when RETPTREF is not available.

Label: Planned Start of Assessment Interval
Notes: Planned start of an assessment interval relative to Time Point Reference (RETPTREF) in ISO 8601 duration format. Example: When the evaluation interval is from 1 to 2 hours after dosing, the value would be PT1H.

Label: Planned End of Assessment Interval
Notes: Planned end of an assessment interval relative to Time Point Reference (RETPTREF) in ISO 8601 duration format. Example: When the evaluation interval is from 1 to 2 hours after dosing, the value would be PT2H.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Subject Identifier for the Study
Notes: Subject (i.e., Animal) identifier used within the study.

Label: Subject Reference Start Date/Time
Notes: Reference start date/time for the subject in ISO 8601 format. Usually equivalent to date/time when subject was first exposed to study treatment. Study day calculation (the --DY variable) in all domains will be based on this date. The sponsor must define what collected date is used to populate RFSTDTC in the data definition file.

Label: Subject Reference End Date/Time
Notes: Reference end date/time for the subject in ISO 8601 format. Usually equivalent to the date/time when the subject was determined to have left the study. The sponsor must define what collected date is used to populate RFENDTC in the data definition file.

Label: Date/Time of First Study Treatment
Notes: First date/time of exposure to any protocol-specified treatment or therapy, equal to the earliest value of EXSTDTC. Note: Absolute first.

Label: Date/Time of Last Study Treatment
Notes: Last date/time of exposure to any protocol-specified treatment or therapy, equal to the latest value of EXENDTC (or the latest value of EXSTDTC if EXENDTC was not collected or is missing). Note: Absolute last

Label: Study Site Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study site within a submission. Use only if subjects are housed at different sites.

Label: Date/Time of Birth
Notes: Date/Time of birth of the subject, in ISO 8601 format.

Label: Age
Notes: May be derived (RFSTDTC - BRTHDTC), but BRTHDTC may not be available in all cases. Age may also be collected.

Label: Age Range
Notes: Used when the age is a range and the exact birthdate is not known. This variable is a character field for the purposes of defining age ranges, e.g., if the information available for the age of the subject is 6-8 and AGEU is WEEKS. Populate only when BRTHDTC or AGE is not specified. The format for AGETXT is "number-number" (e.g., 6-8).

Label: Age Unit
Notes: Units associated with AGE and AGETXT.

Label: Sex
Notes: The sex of the subject.

Label: Species
Notes: If this variable is excluded in the DM domain, the information must be present at a higher level (either Trial Sets or Trial Summary).

Label: Strain/Substrain
Notes: Used to identify the vendor-supplied strain, substrain, or breed designation for the test system under study. It may combine the background strain, substrain, and associated genetic modifications as supplied by the vendor (e.g., C57BL/6, A/J, B6.129-Pparg<tm2Rev>/J, FISCHER 344, SPRAGUE-DAWLEY IGS, WISTAR Kyoto, BEAGLE, CYNOMOLGUS, and CHIMPANZEE). The SEND Controlled Terminology codelist consists of commonly used wild type strains. It is extensible to accommodate strains not listed and genetically modified substrains. If this variable is excluded in the DM domain, the information must be present at a higher level (either Trial Sets or Trial Summary). Country of origin for non-human primates should not go into STRAIN. In general, details related to coat color (e.g., White and Red designations for New Zealand Rabbits) should not go into STRAIN.

Label: Strain/Substrain Details
Notes: Free-text field that allows the sponsor to enter further details qualifiying the SPECIES and/or STRAIN, depending on the level to which these variables were defined. Examples include the description of a specific genetic alteration, country of origin for non-human primates, details related to coat color (e.g., White and Red designations for New Zealand Rabbits), and important animal husbandry information (e.g., SPF, BR, VAF).

Label: Planned Arm Code
Notes: Short name for ARM (may be up to 20 characters) used for sorting and programming. Should be populated when Arms have been defined in the TA domain.

Label: Description of Planned Arm
Notes: Descriptive name given to a specific Trial Arm (e.g., Low Dose, Mid Dose, 10 mg/kg/day dose, Third Arm) to which the subject was assigned.

Label: Set Code
Notes: Short name of a specific Trial Set to which the subject was assigned, as defined by the sponsor. Maximum of 8 characters. This represents the Trial Set for which parameters are being submitted.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Related Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Domain abbreviation of the parent record(s). Null for comments collected as a general comment or additional information.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product. Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated unless the record contains a study comment unrelated to a USUBJID or POOLID.

Label: Pool Identifier
Notes: Identifier used for pooled subjects to assign a single result to multiple subjects. Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated unless the record contains a study comment unrelated to a USUBJID or POOLID.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: The sequence number must be unique for each record within a USUBJID or POOLID, whichever applies for the record.

Label: Identifying Variable
Notes: Variable in the parent dataset that identifies the record(s) to which the comment applies, which is contained in IDVAR. Examples: BWSEQ or CLGRPID. Used only when individual comments are related to domain records.

Label: Identifying Variable Value
Notes: Value of identifying variable of the parent record(s). Used only when individual comments are related to domain records. Cannot be populated if IDVAR is null.

Label: Comment Reference
Notes: Sponsor-defined reference associated with the comment. May be the logbook page number, name (e.g., Logbook), or a combination of information that identifies the reference (e.g., Logbook, page 650, Day 28, morning).

Label: Comment
Notes: The text of the comment. Text over 200 characters can be added to additional columns COVAL1-COVALn. See Assumption 4 in Section 5.2.1.1.

Label: Evaluator
Notes: Used to describe the originator of the comment. Examples: TECHNICIAN, STUDY DIRECTOR, VET.

Label: Date/Time of Comment
Notes: Date/Time of the comment, in ISO 8601 format. May be null if this is a child record of another domain or if the comment date was not collected. In all other cases, this represents the date/time of the comment in ISO 8601 format.

Label: Study Day of Comment
Notes: Study day of the comment, in integer days. May be null if this is a child record of another domain or if the comment date was not collected. The algorithm for calculations must be relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC variable in the Demographics (DM) domain.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a USUBJID within a domain. May be any valid number.

Label: Element Code
Notes: ETCD (the companion to ELEMENT) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions.

Label: Description of Element
Notes: The name of the Element..

Label: Start Date/Time of Element
Notes: Start date/time for an Element for each subject, in ISO 8601 format.

Label: End Date/Time of Element
Notes: End date/time for an Element for each subject, in ISO 8601 format.

Label: Description of Unplanned Element
Notes: Description of what happened to the subject during an unplanned Element. Used only if ETCD has the value of UNPLAN.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Element Code
Notes: ETCD (the short form of ELEMENT) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions.

Label: Description of Element
Notes: The name of the Element.

Label: Rule for Start of Element
Notes: Expresses rule for beginning Element.

Label: Rule for End of Element
Notes: Expresses rule for ending Element. Either TEENRL or TEDUR must be present for each Element; both may be present.

Label: Planned Duration of Element
Notes: Planned duration of Element in ISO 8601 format. Use when an Element represents a fixed duration. TEENRL or TEDUR must be present for each Element; both may be present.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Planned Arm Code
Notes: Short name of a specific ARM (may be up to 20 characters) used for sorting and programming. Should be populated in Demographics when Arms have been defined in this domain.

Label: Description of Planned Arm
Notes: Descriptive name given to a specific Trial Arm (e.g., Low Dose, Mid Dose, 10 mg/kg/day dose).

Label: Order of Element within Arm
Notes: Number that provides the order of the planned Element within the Arm. This value should be an integer.

Label: Element Code
Notes: ETCD (the companion to ELEMENT) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions.

Label: Description of Element
Notes: The name of the Element.

Label: Branch
Notes: Conditions subjects meet, occurring at the end of an Element, which cause an Arm to branch off from other Arms (e.g., randomization to control group).

Label: Transition Rule
Notes: If the study design allows for a subject to transition to an Element other than the next sequential Element, as defined by TAETORD, then the conditions for transitioning to those other Elements, as well as the alternative Element sequences, are specified in this rule (e.g., TATRANS = 'Subject with Hypoactivity Transitions to Rest Period to Treatment 2').

Label: Trial Epoch
Notes: Name of the study Epoch with which this Element of the Arm is associated (e.g., Treatment, Screen). Equivalent to 'Phase' or 'Period.'

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain.

Label: Set Code
Notes: Short name of the Trial Set. The same element may occur more than once within an Arm. Maximum 8 characters. This represents the Trial Set for which parameters are being submitted.

Label: Set Description
Notes: Long description of a specific Trial Set, as defined by the sponsor.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Unique number for this record within this dataset. (This sequence should be unique within the entire dataset because there is no USUBJID.)

Label: Trial Set Parameter Short Name
Notes: Short character value for the Trial Set parameter described in TXPARM. Maximum 8 characters.

Label: Trial Set Parameter
Notes: Term for the Trial Set parameter. Maximum 40 characters.

Label: Trial Set Parameter Value
Notes: Value of the Trial Set parameter (e.g., Fed ad libitum or Restricted Feeding when TXPARM is FEEDREG). Some parameters may be subject to controlled terminology. See the Controlled Terms, Codelist, or Format column in Section 7.4.2 that lists all defined Trial Set parameters.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study within the submission.

Label: Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain most relevant to the observation.

Label: Sequence Number
Notes: Sequence number used to ensure uniqueness within a TSPARMCD. Allows inclusion of multiple records for the same TSPARMCD, and can be used to join related records.

Label: Group Identifier
Notes: Used to tie together a group of related records. This is not the sponsor-defined protocol group number.

Label: Trial Summary Parameter Short Name
Notes: Short character value for the trial design characteristic described in TSPARM. Value must be 8 characters or less.

Label: Trial Summary Parameter
Notes: Term for the trial parameter. Value must be 40 characters or less.

Label: Parameter Value
Notes: Value of the TS parameter (e.g., "FDA" when TSPARM is GLP Type). The values for some parameters may be subject to controlled terminology. See the Controlled Terms, Codelist, or Format column in Section 7.6.3 that lists all defined parameters. TSVAL can only be null if TSVALNF is populated.

Label: Parameter Null Flavor
Notes: Null flavor for the value of the TSPARMs, which should be included according to the trial summary code table below if and only if TSVAL is null.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Related Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain of the parent record(s).

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Unique Subject Identifier of the Parent record(s). Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated, except for certain domain-to-domain relationships (see Section 8.2.3).

Label: Pool Identifier
Notes: Pool Identifier of the Parent record(s). If POOLID is entered, POOLDEF records must exist for each subject and the USUBJID must be null. Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated.

Label: Identifying Variable
Notes: Name of the identifying variable in the general observation class domain that identifies the related record(s). Examples include BWSEQ and BWGRPID.

Label: Identifying Variable Value
Notes: Value of identifying variable described in IDVAR. For example, if BWSEQ is the variable being used to describe this record, then the value of BWSEQ would be entered here.

Label: Relationship Type
Notes: Identifies the hierarchical level of the records in the relationship. Values are only necessary when identifying a relationship between domains (as described in Section 8.4). Values should be either ONE or MANY.

Label: Relationship Identifier
Notes: Unique value within a study that identifies the relationship. RELID can be any value the sponsor chooses and is only meaningful within the df dataset to identify the related/associated domain records.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique study identifier of the parent record(s).

Label: Related Domain Abbreviation
Notes: Two-character abbreviation for the domain of the parent record(s).

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Unique subject identifier of the parent record(s). Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated.

Label: Pool Identifier
Notes: Pool identifier of the Parent record(s).. If POOLID is entered, POOLDEF records must exist for each subject and the USUBJID must be null. Either USUBJID or POOLID must be populated.

Label: Identifying Variable
Notes: Identifying variable in the dataset that identifies the related record(s). Examples: BWSEQ, CLGRPID.

Label: Identifying Variable Value
Notes: Value of identifying variable of the parent record(s).

Label: Qualifier Variable Name
Notes: The short name of the Qualifier variable, which is used as a column name in a domain view with data from the parent domain. The value in QNAM cannot be longer than 8 characters nor can it start with a number (e.g., "1TEST" is not valid). QNAM cannot contain characters other than letters, numbers, or underscores. This will often be the column name in the sponsor's operational dataset. The value in QNAM may not be the same as any variable name defined in another domain or the SDTM. The QNAM should uniquely correspond to a QLABEL within a single domain.

Label: Qualifier Variable Label
Notes: This is the long name or label associated with QNAM. The value in QLABEL should be in title case and cannot be longer than 40 characters. This will often be the column label in the sponsor's operational dataset.

Label: Data Value
Notes: Result of, response to, or value associated with QNAM. A value for this column is required; no records can be in SUPP-- with a null value for QVAL.

Label: Origin
Notes: QORIG is used to indicate the origin of the data. Possible values are COLLECTED, DERIVED, OTHER, and NOT AVAILABLE. See Section 3.2.2.1.

Label: Evaluator
Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (i.e., assigned by a person or a group). Should be null for records that contain objectively collected or derived data. Some examples include PATHOLOGIST or VETERINARIAN, etc.

Label: Study Identifier
Notes: Unique identifier for a study.

Label: Pool Identifier
Notes: Identifier used for pooling subjects to assign a single finding to multiple subjects.

Label: Unique Subject Identifier
Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
